sentence.text: ﻿A 9-year-old girl with short stature was referred to our clinic for differential diagnosis of skeletal dysplasia.
She was born at 39 weeks of gestation.
Her parents were not consanguineous, however, were from the same small village.
Her weight, height, and head circumference were 29.4 kg (0.06 SDS), 105 cm (−4.69 SDS), 53 cm (0.46 SDS), respectively.
She had short stature, relative macrocephaly, depressed nasal bridge, broad nasal tip, and thick lower vermilion.
Short neck, wide and flat thorax, square shoulders, and pes planus were observed (Figure 1).
A bone survey revealed long and slender tubular bones, schmorl nodules and posterior fusion in L4-5 (Figure 2).
Basal GH level was found to be low and a partial GH peak was obtained (Table 1).
An rhGH therapy has been planned to be initiated.
